utterance: RA: As long as we're talking about the issues of of the more societal aspects of decarbonizing economy, which which I think we should would be a good idea to sort of decide whether or not that's something we we really want to tackle here or if it's more the technological or scientific aspects or to what degree they they connect in in a way that we could address meaningfully. But I just wanted to throw in that there are clearly social license aspects along the lines we've been talking about in terms of getting buy-in from society. But one that I've seen that I'm also concerned about uh and Julia uh articulated this well in a way I hadn't heard is the mitigation avoidance um uh protestation which actually I find to be common among scientists that we shouldn't even be thinking about these things because it is an avoidance of what we should be doing to uh reduce emissions in the first place. And at least in the scientific circles that I work in, I meet up with a lot of resistance to even seriously talking about many of the uh fascinating and important and inevitable inevitably necessary technologies and science that we're talking about. I'm not sure that that's something we want to focus on here, but it's just something that I I I find to be uh an obstacle uh in in the circles that I work in.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: JZ explains that the increased soil carbon is not due to the sheep themselves, but the way the farmer manages their grazing, implicitly defining rotational grazing.

utterance: SL: But what about putting hoods, right? So they can suck air and at the same time they are going to suck CO2 and methane. And then they can sell this one as a biogas. This could be a solution. I mean, this was done in my small village with, uh, with some cows around, you know, there was always also birdsman. But there is, okay, what about if you can make biogas with this one? So you can make also money, you know, not only from the cows, but also for buying, you know, for selling by biogas. And with the biogas, you can also just a little bit recirculate in order to make energy in order that you have the hoods that is working, right? So it's more like giving them alternatives that can, can sounds crazy, but at the end of the day, they are not so crazy.

utterance: GG: This was on the cows and poultry. So Roger and Simona, and I think going back to some of the things that Rafael talked about, I think this is a space which is ripe for hybrid technologies. I mean, oftentimes when we talk about negative emission technologies, we have those six or seven technologies in mind, which are, you know, backs or direct air capture or just enhanced weathering. And they're very discreet. And they're very discreet groups of people who actually work on these very discreet set of technologies. But the fact of the matter is that there are a lot of co-benefits and co-gen and, um, I would say synergies that can be obtained by coupling some of these. So for example, if we can come up with pathways for direct air capture and soils. There's a lot that we can learn from the fluid particle interactions, from the mineral and the fluid interactions by just studying, uh, engineered weathering and applying some of those concepts, uh, for direct air capture and soils through weathering, for example. Uh, there could be synergies in the way we use biochar, right? I mean, biochar, I guess the controversy there with biochar is that, you know, you take biomass from location A and put it in location B doesn't necessarily mean that there's been a significant carbon offset, but there could be more creative ways of using biochar so it can be used to maybe capture CO2. I don't know. So I, one way to think about this is to hybridize some of these technologies, hybridize some of these pathways to maybe get them, get us to start thinking about co-benefits. That could be one way. Uh, and again, uh, in the context of biogas, if there, if there are ways, and again, not a plug for what we're doing, but if there is a way for us to remove the CO2 that is co-produced with say the methane and biogas, mineralize that and produce a carbonate at the same time, that is an unconventional way of looking at bioenergy with carbon capture and removal. So there could be pathways in which we could combine weathering with some of these more engineered pathways and vice versa. I think that if there is going to be potential investment, I would encourage, uh, perhaps some of it to go towards some of these hybrid pathways and uncovering the underlying science so that way there is a thermodynamic basis and there is a kinetic basis for these pathways going forward.

annotations.present new idea: GG introduces the concept of hybridizing negative emissions technologies, combining aspects of different approaches to achieve greater CO2 removal.
annotations.expand on existing idea: GG expands on the idea of negative emissions technologies by suggesting specific combinations, such as direct air capture with soils and biochar with CO2 capture.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: GG refers to co-benefits, co-gen, and synergies obtained by coupling technologies, and mentions the potential for a thermodynamic and kinetic basis for these hybrid pathways.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: GG explains that negative emissions technologies typically include six or seven distinct approaches, such as BECCS, direct air capture, and enhanced weathering.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: GG directly addresses Roger and Simona, inviting them to contribute to the discussion on hybrid technologies.

utterance: RA: Andrea, Greeshma raised some questions there that are certainly at the heart of, uh, LCA kind of discussions. What, can you respond to, uh, what you had to say there?

annotations.encourage particpation: Rafael asks Andrea to respond to Greeshma's questions about hybrid technologies and co-benefits in negative emissions technologies, which are central to LCA discussions.

utterance: AH: Yeah, those are actually fabulous questions. Um, you know, I think the fact that we typically think about these very in a siloed perspective of this technology or that technology, that we do need to think about coupling technologies we don't traditionally see. Um, you know, one of my other hats, I work with farmers with our dairy manure waste problem in Wisconsin. You know, and they're always looking for economic pathways. So a lot of them will anaerobically digest their manure and then they're trying to come up with co-products that they can sell that it's great if they're environmentally beneficial. But I mean, they're focused on the economics. Really, if we, going back to Greeshma's point, you know, if we start thinking about adding some of these technologies together, I think that's where you'll see the synergistic benefits. We just have to be careful with how much energy we're consuming and where it comes from.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Andrea acknowledges Greeshma's earlier points about the potential of hybrid technologies for carbon removal.

utterance: RS: On this hybrid approach is another example I can give is that we do here in wealth quite a bit is the production of biochar and then trying to use the biochar to replace coke in steel making. Of course, the big challenge is that the coke in steel making has a very particular morphology, chemical properties, and so on. It's difficult to make a biochar that can directly replace it. But that's one big opportunity to decarbonize steel making. Take biochar and replace coke.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: Roger supports the hybrid approach by giving the example of biochar production replacing coke in steel making, a process researched at Wealth.

utterance: AH: Right. So the waste assessment typically relies on generalized inventories if you don't have particular inventories. So you can think about like anthracite mining, right? utterance: RS: Yeah, one thing I can sort of add to the carbon tech story that we were talking at the beginning is that we have the person who wants to buy the carbon credit, then we have the person doing the sequestration, then we have the market, which is doing the financial transaction. But then we also have the third party verification. Right? So the third party verification needs to have experimental methodologies or simulation software or lifecycle analysis tools to verify that everything that is going on in that in that circle is is actually true. So and and that's something that we need a lot of. I'm I'm part of the peer review board member of Nori, which is the carbon market that's most active right now in the US. And what they are relying currently on is something called, I think it's called Comet. Right? So it's a software that simulates if you do this and this and this to your soil, this will be how much carbon you're sequestering. So it's based on a lot of assumptions and it's based on, yeah, a huge amount of uncertainty. But that's the best they have right now. So that's what they're relying on. But I see that this space needs to grow a lot. So you need much better tools, much better. So that's both experimental and and modeling and predictive tools to really verify that what's going on is actually true.

utterance: JB: One of the things that that struck me in the Ben Cat's assessment was this issue of identifying what the emissions that are most appropriately dealt with by negative emissions might be. And that many of those are going to be in the in the small categories and the things that aren't normally thought of. And that that's certainly an important research topic of establishing criteria for why you would call things appropriate for negative emissions. And and what are those things? So we're also used to thinking about electric power and I kind of agree that electric power looks like it's handled or at least the technology is there.

annotations.expand on existing idea: JB expands on Venkat's summary of the discussion by pointing out the need to identify emissions best suited for negative emissions technologies.
annotations.propose decision: JB proposes to prioritize research on establishing criteria for identifying emissions appropriate for negative emissions technologies.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: JB supports the decision to prioritize research on negative emissions technologies by stating that many emissions best suited for negative emissions technologies fall into small, often overlooked categories.
annotations.express agreement: JB agrees that electricity generation is likely handled with existing technologies, implying a focus on other sectors for negative emissions technologies.

utterance: RA: Julie, what what science would you need to be more convincing to UK government that they should be doing this?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Rafael asks Julia what scientific evidence she needs to convince the UK government to further pursue negative emissions technologies, following the discussion on various decarbonization challenges and potential solutions.

utterance: JB: I mean, I think there is I think there is a lot of work to to do with with our you know, with industries like steel making. I mean, we are I know we we have a number of programs in the UK looking at at zero carbon steel making, looking at hydrogen reduction steel. I know Tata Steel are are actually supporting um quite a lot of that. Yeah. what they might do. And and I think there are some interesting opportunities as well because you get these silicate slags which you which you can then turn into carbonates and essentially use as a you know, as a a negative emission element to the process. So I think there are some interesting studies to be done in some of these hard to decarbonize industries, actually looking at all the steps of their processes and seeing what you could take out or what you could you can turn into a a zero emissions or where there might be a negative emission opportunity. Um it requires quite a lot of detailed understanding of the individual chemical processes or manufacturing processes themselves. But I liked your point about I liked your point about the the small scale emissions because in general, where we get emissions on a large scale, we have some chance of capturing them or you know, it may be it may be that the investment in finding a completely of doing it is is very worthwhile. Where you get lots of very small emitters, that can be that can be very much much harder to do with. I mean, it's much harder to do with emissions from the tailpipe of a of a car than it is from a from a power station. Of course. Actually, of course, there'll be there'll be small scale emissions from the different parts of natural environment that we aren't really able to deal with. But I certainly like the the the techno you know, the tools for techno economic. Because it's small emissions that we aren't really able to deal with.

annotations.expand on existing idea: JB expands on the discussion of negative emissions technologies by focusing on the steelmaking industry and the potential for carbon capture within their processes.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: JB supports their argument by mentioning specific programs in the UK focused on zero-carbon steelmaking and hydrogen reduction steel, citing Tata Steel's support as evidence.
annotations.present new idea: JB introduces the idea of turning silicate slags, a byproduct of steelmaking, into carbonates as a negative emission element.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: JB points out the challenge of dealing with small-scale emissions, arguing that it's harder to capture emissions from many small sources like car tailpipes compared to large point sources like power stations.

utterance: RS: So in addition to a small uh emissions, there's also the fugitive emissions. So fugitive emissions are those cows or uh raising in the in France.
